question: I notice both ration books in WW2 Britain and phone cards in New Zealand have rules about transferring to others - how do they compare?
generated_answer: I don't have enough information to answer the question about comparing rules for transferring ration books in WW2 Britain and phone cards in New Zealand. The documents provided do not contain specific details on the transferability rules for these items.
ground_truth_answer: During WW2, identity cards were strictly non-transferable - it was an offense to allow the card to pass into unauthorized hands or strangers' possession. Similarly, for modern travel to New Zealand, phone SIM cards also have usage restrictions - they can only work in unlocked phones and cannot be shared between networks (for example, Vodafone Australia cards don't work with Vodafone New Zealand despite the same company name).
